claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000, supporting the claim.

attacks.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000, supporting the claim.
The increase in average weekly working hours may be skewed by a rise in part-time or gig economy jobs, which often report higher hours but lower overall labor intensity.
Studies indicate that part-time and gig workers in England still report fewer total hours worked per year compared to full-time employees, making the increase in weekly hours a meaningful trend.
Official statistics may not account for unpaid overtime or remote work, which could mean actual working hours are higher than reported, but this doesn't necessarily contradict the claim.
Surveys show that remote workers in England often work longer hours than office-based employees, reinforcing the claim of increased working time.

supporting.text: Technological advancements and remote work have blurred boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer perceived work hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements and remote work have blurred boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer perceived work hours.
Studies show that actual working hours in England have decreased over the past century due to labor laws and automation.
Perceived work hours may not reflect actual productivity, as remote work can include flexible schedules and breaks.
The blurring of boundaries is offset by increased leisure activities enabled by technology, reducing net work time.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, such as rising living costs, have compelled many in England to work longer hours or take additional jobs.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, such as rising living costs, have compelled many in England to work longer hours or take additional jobs.
Technological advancements and automation have increased productivity, allowing people to complete work more efficiently without needing longer hours.
Despite productivity gains, wage stagnation means many still need to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Government policies, such as flexible working hours and remote work options, have reduced the necessity for extended working hours.
Flexible work policies are not universally adopted, and many industries still require fixed or extended hours.
Historical data shows that average working hours in England have actually decreased over the past century due to labor reforms.
Recent economic crises and inflation have reversed some of these long-term trends, leading to increased working hours in the past decade.

supporting.text: Historical data indicates that the standard workweek in England was shorter in the mid-20th century compared to today.

attacks.text: Historical data indicates that the standard workweek in England was shorter in the mid-20th century compared to today.
Modern flexible work arrangements and remote work may reduce actual working hours despite longer official workweeks.
Studies show that flexible work often leads to 'work creep' where employees work beyond official hours.
Historical data doesn't account for unpaid domestic labor which was more time-consuming in the past.
Domestic labor reduction through technology has been offset by increased professional work demands.
The mid-20th century comparison point was an anomaly during post-war economic rebuilding.
Pre-war workweek data from the 1930s also shows shorter hours than contemporary standards.

supporting.text: Surveys report higher levels of unpaid overtime in England in recent years compared to previous decades.

attacks.text: Surveys report higher levels of unpaid overtime in England in recent years compared to previous decades.
Unpaid overtime does not necessarily equate to overall working time, as paid working hours may have decreased.
Official labor statistics show a decline in average weekly working hours in England over the past decades.
Survey data may be biased due to self-reporting and non-representative samples.
Methodologically rigorous surveys with large sample sizes consistently confirm the trend of increased unpaid overtime.
Higher unpaid overtime could be concentrated in specific sectors, not reflecting the general workforce.
Cross-sector analyses show unpaid overtime increases are widespread across multiple industries.

supporting.text: The decline of union influence and collective bargaining has contributed to longer working hours in some sectors.

attacks.text: The decline of union influence and collective bargaining has contributed to longer working hours in some sectors.
Working hours are regulated by national labor laws, which have become stricter over time, limiting the impact of union decline.
Even with stricter labor laws, enforcement is inconsistent, and employers can exploit loopholes to extend working hours.
Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for long working hours in many sectors.
Automation has also increased productivity expectations, leading to longer hours for workers to meet higher demands.
